S6.T1.caption: Table 1: Performance Metrics on Different Datasets for benign approaches Fedavg, Fedsam, Fedswa vs Proposed (HA-FL) Approach.
S6.T1.table:
Dataset Model F1 Score Accuracy EO Gap
WIDAR Fedavg 0.8648 87.08% 0.4135
Fedsam 0.8896 89.72% 0.4212
Fedswa 0.8703 88.35% 0.3930
HA-FL 0.8012 82.92% 0.3457
EDA Fedavg 0.8064 74.82% 0.3421
Fedsam 0.8280 82.82% 0.2980
Fedswa 0.8161 82.90% 0.2945
HA-FL 0.7946 81.38% 0.2592
HAR Fedavg 0.8424 83.78% 0.4630
Fedsam 0.8894 88.60% 0.4178
Fedswa 0.8431 83.66% 0.4142
HA-FL 0.8347 82.75% 0.4015
references: To investigate, we compare HA-FL with benign FL models (Fedavg, Fedsam, and Fedswa) across three datasets, examining fairness by evaluating the EO gap between ‘sex.’ Results in Table 1 show a notable decrease in the EO gap with HA-FL, indicating enhanced fairness compared to conventional FL methods. While a performance-fairness tradeoff was observed in the WIDAR dataset, which is consistent with prior literature gu2022privacy , our approach maintained accuracy in the other two datasets, showcasing its improved efficacy and fairness balance over benign approaches without using sensitive attribute information during training.

Conventional fairness-enhancing FL methods often require clients with diverse groups of individuals, necessitating data instances from all targeted sensitive attribute groups to attain fairness. For example, to attain sex-wise fairness, these methods require that each client includes both male and female individuals. Notably, HA-FL eliminates this requirement, achieving fairness even with single-person clients by regulating the loss landscape characteristics instead of directly optimizing for fairness-loss during training. Table 3 showcases HA-FL’s performance across the WIDAR dataset, encompassing both single and multi-person data without guaranteed inclusion of all group data instances for sensitive attributes. Client distribution details are available in Appendix D.2. Despite a modest 111% accuracy sacrifice compared to Table 1, HA-FL notably reduces the EO Gap, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving fairness without imposing strict inclusion requirements.

To assess its effectiveness, we computed fairness regarding other sensitive attributes besides ‘sex’: ‘hands’ and ‘orientation’ concerning the sensor, for the same models evaluated in Table 1 for the EDA and WIDAR datasets, respectively. HAR has only one sensitive attribute, ‘sex,’ hence, this section excludes HAR evaluation. The results, summarized in Table 4, demonstrate notable improvements in fairness across other sensitive attributes as well.

Notably, the EO gap reduction in the EDA dataset was achieved with a modest sacrifice of 111% in F1 score than the Table 1 results when considering the sensitive attribute left and right “hand." A similar result is observed for the WIDAR dataset, showcasing enhanced fairness across multiple attributes simultaneously

The evaluation results are presented in rows highlighted in ‘blue’ in Table 10. First, these results consistently demonstrate that across all datasets, HA-FL’s aggregation strategy, as outlined in Equations 2 and 3, outperforms others. Meaning this evaluation
confirms that integrating both classification and top eigenvalue loss and favoring clients with lower loss (as outlined in Equations 2 and 3) enhances the balance between efficacy and fairness.

Furthermore, the fact that fairer models are achieved even without local client-side fairness constraints in these evaluations, compared to the benign baselines presented in rows highlighted in ‘red’ in Table 10, establishes that HA-FL’s Sharpness-aware aggregation independently promotes ‘fairness without demographics.’

This section evaluates the independent effect of Sharpness-aware client-side local training as outlined in Equation 1 to enhance ‘fairness without demographics.’
To conduct this evaluation, we implemented a variant where client-side local training incorporates fairness constraints based on Equation 1, while employing a benign aggregation scheme where all weights in Equation 2 are set to ‘1.’ To ensure a fair comparison, the SWA aggregation strategy, outlined in Algorithm 1, remains employed in this approach. The evaluation results are showcased in rows highlighted in ‘yellow’ in Table 10, indicating its superior enhancement of fairness compared to the benign approaches depicted in ‘red’ highlighted rows across all datasets. This underscores the independent influence of client-side sharpness-aware local training in enhancing ‘fairness without demographics.’

The evaluations discussed above have demonstrated that both the Sharpness-Aware Aggregation Strategy, outlined in Equations 2 and 3, and the Sharpness-Aware client-side local training, depicted by Equation 1 in the main paper, independently contribute to promoting fairness. However, these individual strategies exhibit less effectiveness (fairness and efficacy balance) compared to the presented HA-FL approach, which incorporates both strategies, as indicated by the ‘green’ highlighted rows across all datasets in Table 10. This underscores the effectiveness of Algorithm 1 in attaining ‘fairness without demographics.’

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Comparison of HA-FL with the ’Equalized Odds (EO) Loss with Fedavg’ and ’Fairbatch (FB) with Fedavg’ models
S6.T2.table:
Dataset Model F1 Score Accuracy EO Gap
EO-Fedavg 0.8358 85.21% 0.3725
WIDAR FB-Fedavg 0.8134 82.39% 0.3892
HA-FL 0.8012 82.92% 0.3457
EO-Fedavg 0.7705 74.57% 0.2574
EDA FB-Fedavg 0.7611 72.11% 0.2627
HA-FL 0.7946 81.38% 0.2592
EO-Fedavg 0.8357 82.89% 0.4178
HAR FB-Fedavg 0.8315 83.01% 0.3761
HA-FL 0.8347 82.75% 0.4015
references:
To investigate, we compared HA-FL with SOTA fairness-aware FL methods like ‘Fairbatch with Fedavg’ roh2020fairbatch  and ‘Equalized odds loss with Fedavg’ fairtorch . Details of these methods are in Appendix B.3.
These methods ensure fairness by considering specific known factors/attributes during FL training. However, the former method roh2020fairbatch  compromises FL’s privacy-preserving nature as clients share such information with servers. The evaluation results are shown in Table 2, where the known fairness attaining factor/attribute during training for the two fairness-aware methods is ‘sex,’ and the EO gap in respect to ‘sex’ is computed for fairness comparisons.
HA-FL, without prior knowledge during training, achieves comparable fairness. Notably, observing the lowest EO gaps for WIDAR, EDA, and HAR (0.340.340.34, 0.240.240.24, and 0.370.370.37, respectively), our approach matches the best gaps in WIDAR and EDA and is comparable to the best-performing approach in the HAR dataset. This outcome represents a significant advancement and introduces a more privacy-preserving and adaptable solution for fairness in FL.

To compare the efficacy of HA-FL with SOTA known-fairness aware strategies (under RQ-2), we adapted an evaluations framework similar to the prior work by Zheng et al. zeng2021improving . Their work modified the standard Fedavg protocol to incorporate fairness directly into the FL process by introducing fair training mechanisms at the client level, like fairbatch roh2020fairbatch . Along with fairbatch roh2020fairbatch , we incorporate another fair training mechanism like Equalized-odds (EO) loss fairtorch ; agarwal2018reductions , which is another SOTA framework for centralized fair training. The integration of the SOTA known-fairness mechanisms at the client level did improve fairness compared to the conventional Fedavg but came at the cost of privacy in line with the prior findings zeng2021improving . HA-FL, however, has the advantage of being privacy-preserving and providing better or equivalent fairness benefits without significant performance trade-offs, as illustrated in Table 2 in the main paper.

Table 3 showcases HA-FL’s performance across the WIDAR dataset, encompassing both single and multi-person data without guaranteed inclusion of all group data instances for sensitive attributes. Despite a modest 111% accuracy sacrifice compared to Table 1, HA-FL notably reduces the EO Gap, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving fairness without imposing strict inclusion requirements.

A4.T8.caption: Table 8: Hyperparameters for benign Fedavg model
A4.T8.table:
Hyperparameter WIDAR EDA HAR
Learning Rate 0.1 0.1 0.001
Epochs 3 3 3
Total Round 80 80 100
references:
The approach uses several hyperparameters for Benign and HA-FL model training. Table 8 and 9 shows the hyperparameter values for benign and HA-FL model training, respectively. These values correspond to the best results obtained using a grid search.
Within the context of the HA-FL model, the SWA Learning Rate specifically denotes the learning rate at which the SWA model is introduced into the training process. The SWA Start Round is indicative of the round at which the SWA mechanism is initiated. Additionally, the cycle parameter signifies that post the initiation of SWA, the global model and learning rate undergo updates using SWA in a cyclic manner, with each cycle representing a distinct iteration of this process. The term ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon pertains to the weighting value, which ensures the maintenance of the relative ranks of each client during the aggregation process. Opting for a smaller value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon proved beneficial for better ranking precision.

The evaluation results are presented in rows highlighted in ‘blue’ in Table 10. First, these results consistently demonstrate that across all datasets, HA-FL’s aggregation strategy, as outlined in Equations 2 and 3, outperforms others. Meaning this evaluation
confirms that integrating both classification and top eigenvalue loss and favoring clients with lower loss (as outlined in Equations 2 and 3) enhances the balance between efficacy and fairness.

Furthermore, the fact that fairer models are achieved even without local client-side fairness constraints in these evaluations, compared to the benign baselines presented in rows highlighted in ‘red’ in Table 10, establishes that HA-FL’s Sharpness-aware aggregation independently promotes ‘fairness without demographics.’

This section evaluates the independent effect of Sharpness-aware client-side local training as outlined in Equation 1 to enhance ‘fairness without demographics.’
To conduct this evaluation, we implemented a variant where client-side local training incorporates fairness constraints based on Equation 1, while employing a benign aggregation scheme where all weights in Equation 2 are set to ‘1.’ To ensure a fair comparison, the SWA aggregation strategy, outlined in Algorithm 1, remains employed in this approach. The evaluation results are showcased in rows highlighted in ‘yellow’ in Table 10, indicating its superior enhancement of fairness compared to the benign approaches depicted in ‘red’ highlighted rows across all datasets. This underscores the independent influence of client-side sharpness-aware local training in enhancing ‘fairness without demographics.’

The evaluations discussed above have demonstrated that both the Sharpness-Aware Aggregation Strategy, outlined in Equations 2 and 3, and the Sharpness-Aware client-side local training, depicted by Equation 1 in the main paper, independently contribute to promoting fairness. However, these individual strategies exhibit less effectiveness (fairness and efficacy balance) compared to the presented HA-FL approach, which incorporates both strategies, as indicated by the ‘green’ highlighted rows across all datasets in Table 10. This underscores the effectiveness of Algorithm 1 in attaining ‘fairness without demographics.’
